Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Augmented Reality Headset for Training in Acetabular Component Positioning

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, 24 final-year medical students with no prior arthroplasty experience were recruited.

Participants.evidence: 24 final-year medical students with no prior arthroplasty experience were recruited.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: AR training with live holographic feedback and hands-on training by an expert surgeon.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates an augmented reality (AR) headset as a training tool for acetabular component positioning in simulated total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the orientation error in degrees between planned and achieved orientations, measured over four weekly sessions.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 24 final-year medical students with no prior arthroplasty experience were recruited.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AR group had a mean orientation error of 6° ± 4°, while the surgeon group had 1° ± 1° (p < 0.001). Both groups improved over the sessions, with no significant difference in final accuracy (mean difference 1.2°, 95% CI, -1.8 to 4.2°; p = 0.281).
